newsArray.title: Dubai Stadium pitch report Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan: Is Dubai International Stadium pitch report for bowlers?
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: Dubai Stadium pitch report Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan: The stadium is set to host the first match of Asia Cup 2022 today. Sri Lanka is set to face-off against Afghanistan in the first â€˜Group Bâ€™ match of Asia Cup 2022 at the Dubai International Stadium today. As for the recent T20 format form, Afghanistan haveâ€¦ The post Dubai Stadium pitch report Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan: Is Dubai International Stadium pitch report for bowlers? appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Dubai Stadium pitch report Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan: The stadium is set to host the first match of Asia Cup 2022 today. Sri Lanka is set to face-off against Afghanistan in the first â€˜Group Bâ€™ match of Asia Cup 2022 at the Dubai International Stadium today. As for the recent T20 format form, Afghanistan have arrived UAE with a on the back of a better form compared to Sri Lanka. Despite losing 3-2 against Ireland in the five-match T20I series around a week ago, they did manage to defeat Afghanistan (3-0), and draw Bangladesh (1-1) in the other two shortest format series this year. Having said that, it remains to be seen how they perform against top-ranked sides in the battle for the continental supremacy. Sri Lanka, on the other hand, have managed to win just a couple of T20Is off the eleven they have played this year. In fact, they have managed to win just one T20I series since the year 2020, against a second string Indian side. The Dasun Shanaka-led side has lost twice against Australia and once against India in the shortest format series this year. All in all, Sri Lanka will surely start as favourites on the back of a comparatively stronger batting line-up than Afghanistan, on the basis of T20 skill-sets. Both the teams will play only their second T20I today, having last played during the 2016 T20 World Cup in India. The Countdown has begun!â³ Just 24 hours left for the #AsiaCup2022 curtain raiser! ğŸ¤© ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡° âš”ï¸ ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡« | August 27th | 07:30PM (SLST) #RoaringForGlory pic.twitter.com/LfdcvAwrv1 â€” Sri Lanka Cricket ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡° (@OfficialSLC) August 26, 2022 The Dubai international Stadium is set to host its first T20I since the grand finale of the 2021 T20I World Cup in November between Australia and New Zealand. While the presence of dew during the World Cup here last year did play a huge role, the past few nights at this venue has not experienced much dew, which makes the case for an balanced contest between bat and the ball. For record, the chasing teams have won 13 off the 14 T20Is at this venue since 2019, with the pitch assisting the bowlers for large parts of these contests. Since last year, not once has the team total breached the 200-run mark. In fact, the average score across the 75 T20Is at this venue since 2009 is 144.6. Thus, all in all, the bowlers, especially the spinners, are likely to have much of a say during the first match of Asia Cup 2022 today.

newsArray.title: England in strong position to level South Africa series after incredible Ben Stokes and Ben Foakes centuries on day two
creator: John Etheridge
newsArray.content: BEN STOKES scripted another new scene in his dramatic life story by scoring his first century as England captain. On the day when a documentary about Stokes was released, the man himself played a starring role in a dominating England performance. APBen Stokes celebrates his first century as England captain[/caption] APBen Foakes raises his arms aloft after scoring his century[/caption] He scored 103 and a second Test century from Ben Foakes propelled England to a position where they will surely win the Second Test against South Africa and level the series. Stokes played an innings of rare distinction. Nothing foolish, nothing too aggressive, just brilliant and near-faultless batting at a perfect tempo. Stokes and Foakes revitalised Englandâ€™s innings so effectively that they went from scores of 43-3 and 147-5 to a total of 415-9 declared. South African openers Dean Elgar and Sarel Erwee negotiated nine overs at the end of the second day and will resume this morning with 23-0 â€“ still 241 runs behind. Read More Cricket Stories BEEFY'S BEEF Moment cricket legend Ian Botham is ambushed by masked shooting protesters PRIZE TIME Enter for chance to win a Lamborghini + Â£5,000 from just 89p with The Sun's code The Stokes film focuses on his mental health struggles, the death of his father Ged and his period away from cricket last year. There have been plenty of tough times but this was a day of pure joy for Stokes as he reined in some of the extremes of â€˜Bazballâ€™ that his batting has displayed this summer. Few could have played better and with such authority. He never forgets his late dad and looked to the heavens and did his regular â€œmissing fingerâ€ salute as a tribute to a man who once had a digit amputated in order to prolong his rugby league career. Foakes said: â€œBen is a great guy to bat with, he takes the pressure off you and he really raced away when moving from fifty to 100. Most read in Cricket 'I WAS WRONG' Ballance apologises to old pal Rafiq for 'unacceptable and racist' language A SPIN OFF All the England fixtures and results from a packed 2022 schedule BEEFY'S BEEF Moment cricket legend Ian Botham is ambushed by masked shooting protesters IN A STU Broad ready to miss England tour of Pakistan with fiancee Mollie due to give birth NEW DUKES What is the new ball in Test cricket and when can bowlers use it? RIP RUDI Tributes paid to late cricket umpire Rudi Koertzen after car crash JOIN SUN VEGAS: GET A FREE Â£10 BONUS WITH 100s OF GAMES TO PLAY AND NO DEPOSIT REQUIRED (Ts&Cs apply) â€œHeâ€™s got a few good things going on his life â€“ everyone wanted a piece of him. And itâ€™s a great film as well. The way he played was pretty special.â€ It must be said that South Africa skipper Elgar had a tactical shocker to follow his erroneous decision on day one to bat first in overcast conditions. In particular, Elgar strangely under bowled speedster Anrich Njorte at the key moments. Stokes struck three sixes, the biggest of which was a mighty blow off spinner Simon Harmer over long-on that took him to his half-century. His hundred arrived with a drive back to Kasigo Rabada, who ended up inadvertently kicking the ball to square leg and allowing Stokes to run a single. Soon after, Stokes attempted a big hit and skied a catch to mid-off. Foakesâ€™ batting was almost as neat and polished as his wicketkeeping, which is saying something. He has endured setbacks â€“ such as a torn hamstring last summer when he slipped in the Surrey dressing room and a debilitating dose of Covid this summer. And he has been under pressure for a lack of runs at No.7 but his second Test century â€“ his first was on debut in Sri Lanka nearly four years ago â€“ will silence those comments. Foakes hardly ever missed with his favourite shots through mid-wicket and was certainly happy when Elgar seemed so reluctant to utilise Nortjeâ€™s 94mph thunderbolts after lunch. Foakes now has as many Test hundreds in 30 innings as Jos Buttler has made in 100 innings. Batting was tricky at the start and Nortje dismissed both Jonny Bairstow and Zak Crawley before England, resuming on 111-3, were level with South Africaâ€™s first innings total of 151 all out. But those blokes, Stokes and Foakes, put England miles ahead in the match with a sixth-wicket stand of 173. Stokes was given out lbw to Lungi Ngidi on 72 but replays showed an inside edge. And he was dropped on 92 by Aiden Markram leaping to his right at cover, a difficult chance. Foakes was given out lbw to Keshav Maharaj on 28 but replays showed the ball pitched outside legside and was also missing off. Otherwise, they were in almost complete control. In fact, Stokes was caused most discomfort when his left knee suddenly locked up early in his innings and he needed treatment, not for the first time this summer. Read More on The Sun TATT'S AWFUL Tattooist shows off freckles she gave to a clientâ€¦ but people are horrified STRICTLY SERIOUS Strictly 'in chaos over schedule clash leaving bosses fearing backlash' After Stokes departed, Stuart Broad got off the mark with a straight six, Ollie Robinson whacked a couple of boundaries and Jack Leach swatted a switch hit for four. The lower-order was having some fun. No.11 James Anderson did not even both to pad up and Stokesâ€™ declaration left his bowlers a blast at South Africaâ€™s openers. But they could not make a breakthrough.

newsArray.title: How Tassie star bounced back from the brink for premiership shot
newsArray.description: ALEX Pearce has had a cracking season on the footy field, with the key defender helping to secure the Fremantle Dockers a spot as one of the final eight teams that will battle it out for the AFL premiership flag in coming weeks.
newsArray.content: Itâ€™s an exciting time for the 27-year-old Tasmanian, who has been part of the clubâ€™s leadership group for the past few years and has stepped up as his teamâ€™s stand-in leader for much of this season because of captain Nat Fyfeâ€™s struggles with injury.Itâ€™s also an experience Pearce doesnâ€™t take for granted, after having faced numerous personal setbacks since making his Dockers debut in 2015 that, at times, left him wondering whether his professional sporting career was over.The 201cm, 99kg key forward â€“ who was capable of becoming a defender â€“ was drafted to the Dockers at the end of 2013. He made his debut in Round 6 of the 2015 AFL season, helping the Dockers secure a win over Essendon in front of a crowd of 37,500 at Domain Stadium (also known as Subiaco Oval). Pearce quickly captured the attention of fans and earned himself a reputation as one of the teamâ€™s most promising youngsters.As 2016 kicked off, Pearce was considered a shining light for the Dockers in an otherwise dour season that was peppered with a string of losses.However, Pearce broke his right shinbone (tibia) during an on-field clash in a game against Richmond in Round 9, which resulted in him missing the remainder of that season and all of the 2017 season as well. His recovery was delayed as he suffered a partial fracture to the same leg during the 2017 pre-season.Pearce underwent surgery and began rehabilitation, including a stint in Los Angeles.Seeing Pearceâ€™s potential, his club showed unwavering support throughout his recovery and Pearce made his comeback in 2018, seemingly in fine form, despite 672 days having lapsed between his 21st and 22nd AFL matches.However, disaster struck again in 2019 when Pearce fractured his left ankle in a Round 11 match against Collingwood at the MCG, forcing him out for the rest of the season and for the entire 2020 season â€“ resulting in a further 658 days on the sidelines.It was a devastating blow for Pearce, who was again left contemplating whether his football career was at an end. â€œObviously plenty of thoughts went through my head during that period â€¦ that career that Iâ€™ve dreamt of and wanted might not be there and it might not be my choice, I might have no say in things,â€™â€™ Pearce recalls of that time. â€œIt was really challenging to confront my football mortality in a way.â€™â€™He says when he suffered the initial tibia injury, he was disappointed but was initially confident he could recover and return quickly.â€œThe first (injury) I was sort of really young and just generally excited about everything and just took it in my stride a bit and was just ready to get to rehab and come back the next year and be all good,â€™â€™ he says.He didnâ€™t anticipate heâ€™d miss the rest of the season as well as the entire season after that.Suffering the ankle injury was a further blow, but Pearce says despite the â€œincredibly difficultâ€ time and the multiple surgeries and extensive rehab, his passion for playing football never wavered. â€œI guess during that time you have a lot of time to think about what you really want and whether Iâ€™m really committed to come back and do it all again,â€™â€™ he says of recovering from injury.â€œAnd during that time I realised that yep, Iâ€™m still really committed, and Iâ€™m willing to train and willing to rehab and willing to come back and still believe that I could get to a level where I could be a really successful player, in a really successful team, and thatâ€™s what sort of drove me through that period.â€™â€™He says the fact that the team that stuck by him throughout his injuries is enjoying success this year was made sweeter because of the hurdles he had to overcome to get where he is today.â€œYeah, it has definitely been nice,â€™â€™ he says of the successful 2022 season. â€œFrom a personal point of view, to be able play the majority of the games, Iâ€™ve had a couple of little injuries along the way, Iâ€™ve missed three games this year, but all in all Iâ€™ve been able to stay out there, which has been really nice.â€œFrom the middle of last year Iâ€™ve been able to play some consistent footy and probably the most consistent footy Iâ€™ve ever played.â€œCombining that with a little bit of team success this year, thatâ€™s obviously been great. Weâ€™ve spent a few years struggling a bit; last year we had a few wins and we were sort of challenging for that top eight. And then this year to be able to start the season well, and be hovering around that top four (after last weekendâ€™s games, the club finished fifth on the AFL ladder, going into finals) â€¦ itâ€™s definitely nice. It gives this time of year a bit more meaning and to be a part of that and embrace the passion of our fans and everything, it has just been fantastic.â€™â€™ Not one to get carried away by the hype, Pearce remains true to his initial goal when he made his AFL debut, which was to work on being a strong, reliable player.â€œI guess that first thing is to just be a consistent player that is picked every week and that is a part of the team,â€™ Pearce says.â€œIt was probably 2016 where I was at that stage where I was playing and my spot was reasonably assured. I was starting to build towards really being one of best defenders in the comp, and that was my goal â€“ I wanted to be the best defender in the competition.â€œAnd from that time in 2016 to now Iâ€™ve had a lot of setbacks, obviously, and spent more time off the field in rehab than what I have on it.â€œBut I feel like Iâ€™m performing reasonably well â€¦ I think Iâ€™ve still got more to give.â€œThis will be nearly the most games Iâ€™ve played in a season in over an 18-month stretch so I feel like Iâ€™ve got plenty more improvement in me â€¦ from a personal point of view, Iâ€™ve been happy with how things have been able to go.â€™â€™He says it has been nice to get some momentum, which he hopes will continue well into the future.â€œI guess the biggest thing for me is just being able to train consistently and play consistently,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œEven though Iâ€™ve played a lot this season, due to soreness and little injuries Iâ€™ve been quite hampered in my training this year, so I feel like if I can maintain my fitness over the off-season and the pre-season, that will help build a bit more resilience and Iâ€™ll be able to be a bit more unrestricted in my training next season.â€™â€™He also finds it rewarding to act as a mentor for younger players coming through the ranks.â€œWeâ€™re still a relatively young team,â€™â€™ Pearce says of the current Dockers line-up.â€œIâ€™m more of a senior player and leader now so to keep trying to grow the players around me, particularly our defensive group, weâ€™re really tight and I really love playing with those eight or nine guys who I spend a lot of time with each day, so to keep making them the best they can be is a real driver.â€™â€™However, he admits heâ€™s not getting too comfortable, despite the success of this season.â€œItâ€™s probably just my personality that I donâ€™t allow myself to get too comfortable or too content with things,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œThe football cycle is so quick, and one week to another you can be flying on top of the world and the next week you come crashing down.â€œItâ€™s a challenge and itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve tried to learn, I guess, to try and stay a bit level-headed throughout all of these ups and downs. â€œI think particularly the role Iâ€™ve had of being a leader and being captain for a lot of times this year I can often feel a bit more pressure and itâ€™s harder to stay a bit more level and a bit more balanced â€¦ but itâ€™s all part of the learning experience.â€™â€™Pearce is thankful his club stuck by him, and invested heavily in him in terms of his rehab, recovery and support.â€œIâ€™ve been incredibly fortunate I guess that thereâ€™s been multiple times when Iâ€™ve been negotiating a contract and I havenâ€™t played much footy and Iâ€™ve been injured and the club has continued to back me in and has shown a lot of trust me in,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œIâ€™ve just signed a contract this year for another three years, which again was another sign of faith, and I hope that Iâ€™ve been able to give back a little bit and repay that faith and thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ll be trying to do over the next few years. â€œTo be a part of our leadership group for the last four or five years and to captain the club this year was probably one of my proudest moments. â€œIâ€™m currently doing that at the moment with Nathan (Fyfe) out, itâ€™s an experience that I certainly donâ€™t take for granted and itâ€™s probably one of the most special things Iâ€™ve been able to do in my career so far.â€™â€™Pearce, who grew up in Ulverstone, says sport was a huge part of his childhood â€“ most of his early memories relate to sport in some way.â€œI grew up playing sport from when I could walk, pretty much,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œMy dad played bit of footy at Ulverstone but mainly he played a lot of cricket. My mum was quite sporty, she played soccer for Ulverstone and a few other sports.â€œSo my upbringing was watching my parents play sport. I used to spend my summer weekends down at the cricket watching dad from pretty much when I could walk and they were my earliest memories. And then during the winter Iâ€™d spend all day watching the footy â€¦ watching the Robins (Ulverstone Football Club) play. So yeah, sport has always been a huge part of my life, particularly sport around Ulverstone.â€™â€™Pearce enjoyed playing footy and cricket the most â€“ he continued playing cricket until he was drafted. But he also played golf â€“ he won a national golfing title in grade nine â€“ and he was also a talented long-distance runner. Pearce laughs as he recalls running against â€“ and losing to â€“ Stewart McSweyn at high school, who went on to compete at the Tokyo Olympics in 2020.The turning point came for Pearce at 17, when a football opportunity unexpectedly came knocking.â€œI wasnâ€™t a part of the Under-16 Tasmanian team; I was happy playing footy at Ulverstone at the time, and played cricket in the summer,â€™â€™ Pearce recalls.â€œAnd then there was an injury in the Under-16 team, and I got a late call up and got the opportunity to play as a 17-year-old, so I was an over-age player, and that was right towards the end of the footy season. So I just parachuted in pretty much and went to one training session and went over to Sydney, I think it was, and played in the Under-16 carnival and played really well and from there that was when I started getting a bit of attention.â€He recalls getting a letter from an AFL player manager, which was a â€œsurrealâ€ experience.â€œIt was like â€˜OK, people are actually taking noticeâ€™,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œNext season I was part of the Under-18 Tassie Mariners, so I had to move clubs and play at Devonport for that year. That season, being able to play some good footy for Devonport and being able to play OK in the national carnivals was, I guess, what got me drafted and that was a pretty exciting experience. That whole season, knowing that every time I went out there, there was a chance there were AFL clubs watching and that I was going to have an opportunity to get myself drafted. And lucky enough I did.â€™â€™Pearce had been considering moving to Melbourne after finishing school to study physiotherapy at university and hopefully play in the VFL if he didnâ€™t get drafted. â€œI think I always dreamt of playing sport,â€™â€™ he says.â€œI always wanted to play test cricket for Australia, that was my No 1 thing.â€™â€™But he was also savvy enough to understand that he needed to have a back-up plan.â€œI always dreamt of being a professional athlete, a footballer or cricketer, but I feel like I had enough awareness to know that even if you do play sport full-time, you need to have another career because sporting careers donâ€™t last that long,â€™â€™ Pearce says.Getting drafted obviously changed these plans, but that hasnâ€™t stopped Pearce from furthering his education.A couple of years ago, he started a bachelor of arts majoring is psychology and politics and says it has been good to have another interest besides football.â€œAt this stage itâ€™s a really nice outlet to be able to have something that Iâ€™m invested in and it helps take my mind off football, and it takes a lot of mental capacity to keep up with everything, it keeps me quite busy,â€™â€™ Pearce says of studying.â€œI guess I learnt going through my injuries that itâ€™s really hard to deal with setback and disappointment when your whole life revolves around football and at the moment I feel like Iâ€™ve got a lot more balance in my life.â€œIf I have a bad week of football or if something goes wrong, Iâ€™ve got more to keep my mind active, and more sense of fulfilment and happiness in other things.â€™â€™Pearce does miss Tassie, and while moving to the other side of the country to play football posed some challenges, he feels like he has found his feet in Western Australia. â€œWhen I initially got drafted, I knew I was gonna have to move regardless and I was no certainty to get drafted at all, so to get drafted anywhere I was just super excited,â€™â€™ he says.â€œI guess Iâ€™ve always been a pretty independent person, so I havenâ€™t had too much homesickness. And moving into a football club environment I was lucky to find a lot of mates within the club and most of the guys are sort of my age and have got similar interests so that made the transition pretty easy.â€œProbably the Covid years were the hardest couple, just knowing there was a period I couldnâ€™t get back, even if I wanted to â€¦ that was probably where I felt a little bit of homesickness.â€œTowards the end of the Covid period when Tassie and WA had that little travel bubble, I was able to get back and forth quite a bit, I was really lucky compared to some of my Victorian teammates.â€œIâ€™ve always come back (to Tassie) at least a couple of times a year. Most recently we had our mid-season bye and I came back for about four days and caught up with a few people and just enjoyed some time in Tassie, which I always love to do.â€™â€™The basketball enthusiast is an avid Tasmania JackJumpers fan. Due to his footy commitments and being based in Perth, Pearce hasnâ€™t managed to attend a live game yet, but heâ€™s an inaugural member and follows the teamâ€™s progress online, proudly donning his JackJumpers jersey whenever Tassie gets a win.Pearce says it has been great to see the support Tasmanians have shown the JackJumpers and heâ€™d love to see the same support for a Tasmanian AFL side.â€œThe enthusiasm that (basketball) has created around the state can easily be matched and outdone by a Tasmanian footy team,â€™â€™ he says.He says itâ€™s an exciting prospect that his home state appears to be getting closer to having its own AFL team.â€œIâ€™m super excited for the possibility,â€™â€™ Pearce says.â€œI still very much identify as a Tasmanian and a lot of my teammates and coaches are sick of me going on about the JackJumpers and every Tasmanian sporting team there is. I grew up being sports crazy, and I think young kids in Tassie deserve the opportunity to dream about one day representing their state in the AFL.â€œI think weâ€™ve got a really rich history of contributions from players and coaches, weâ€™ve given a lot to the game of football, and I feel like the Tassie community in general would really embrace a team. â€œObviously Iâ€™m a huge supporter and hopefully this push feels a bit different and it feels like weâ€™ve got some real momentum behind us so hopefully it can get off the ground sooner rather than later.â€™â€™So how would Pearce feel about playing against his home state in the AFL?â€œWho knows â€¦ it would be a nice problem to have,â€™â€™ he says.For now, of course, his sights are set on the 2022 AFL premiership. The Fremantle Dockers have made it to finals before, but since joining the league in 1994 the club has never managed to win a premiership.â€œWe donâ€™t shy away, we want to be the first to win a premiership for Freo, and it would be incredibly special, obviously, to do that,â€™â€™ Pearce says. â€œI feel really connected to Fremantle â€“ the place and our playing group and our fans. And it would mean a lot, not just to myself and my teammates, but for everyone who has represented Freo and has supported us along the way.â€™â€™â€¢Following the pre-finalsâ€™ bye, Fremantle will play an elimination final against the Western Bulldogs at Optus Stadium, in Perth, on September 3, kicking off at 8.10pm Tasmanian time..

newsArray.title: â€œIf he would have playedâ€¦â€: KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have been a good experience for Indian batters during Asia Cup 2022
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have mattered for the Indian team as has been the case with left-arm pacers lately. Indiaâ€™s wicket-keeper batter KL Rahul did not rule out the highly likely Shaheen Shah Afridi threat, as team India are set to take on Pakistan in their opening match of the Asia Cupâ€¦ The post â€œIf he would have playedâ€¦â€: KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have been a good experience for Indian batters during Asia Cup 2022 appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have mattered for the Indian team as has been the case with left-arm pacers lately. Indiaâ€™s wicket-keeper batter KL Rahul did not rule out the highly likely Shaheen Shah Afridi threat, as team India are set to take on Pakistan in their opening match of the Asia Cup 2022 on August 28, at the Dubai International Stadium. Pakistan fans were handed a huge blow last week when their 22-year-old champion fast bowler was rule out due to a right knee ligament injury, which he had picked up during the first Test of Pakistanâ€™s tour of Sri Lanka last month. While some Cricket experts blame the Pakistani skipper and the team management for their careless approach in handling Afridiâ€™s injury, the current crop of players do believe that the other pacers in their squad are match-winners as well, and can take on any side in the tournament. As for the Indian side, questions were also raised on KL Rahulâ€™s inclusion in the teamâ€™s squad for the Asia Cup, while star batter Virat Kohli is set to garner the maximum spotlights during the high-octane clash between the arch-rivals, for not the positive of reasons. KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have mattered Pakistan fans and some of the former cricketers have explicitly expressed their fear regarding the absence of a left-arm pacer in their team squad, as they have proved to be a cause of worry, especially for the Indian top-order during the recent T20I bilateral series against West Indies and England. Without beating around the bush or shying away from expressing his vulnerability on the same, KL Rahul did admit that the left-arm seamers around the world are indeed causing troubles for the batters, and that it would have been a great experience for his team to take on someone of the caliber of Shaheen Afridi, who is unarguably one of the best at the moment in International Cricket. â€œShaheen Shah Afridi is a world-class bowler, he is a quality bowler. Left-arm seamers right now in world cricket are the most dangerous and they are causing problems for batters. If he would have played, it would have been a good experience for us. Unfortunately, he is injured,â€ Rahul said while addressing a press conference on Friday. Both Rahul and Afridi were seen conversing with each other a day before, while the former was heading towards the practice session in Dubai. Stars align ahead of the #AsiaCup2022 A high-profile meet and greet on the sidelines pic.twitter.com/c5vsNCi6xw â€” Pakistan Cricket (@TheRealPCB) August 25, 2022 For more Cricket-related news, click here. The post â€œIf he would have playedâ€¦â€: KL Rahul reckons Shaheen Afridiâ€™s presence would have been a good experience for Indian batters during Asia Cup 2022 appeared first on The SportsRush.

newsArray.title: â€œBloody hundredâ€: Ben Foakes smashes his first Test century in England and vs South Africa at Old Trafford in Manchester
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: Ben Foakes smashes his first Test century at home and only his second overall, as England continue to dominate proceedings at Old Trafford. During â€˜Day 2â€™ of the second Test of South Africaâ€™s ongoing tour of England at the Old Trafford in Manchester, England wicket-keper batter Ben Foakes has smashed his second Test century, andâ€¦ The post â€œBloody hundredâ€: Ben Foakes smashes his first Test century in England and vs South Africa at Old Trafford in Manchester appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Ben Foakes smashes his first Test century at home and only his second overall, as England continue to dominate proceedings at Old Trafford. During â€˜Day 2â€™ of the second Test of South Africaâ€™s ongoing tour of England at the Old Trafford in Manchester, England wicket-keper batter Ben Foakes has smashed his second Test century, and his first against the visitors, to take his teamâ€™s lead to 264 runs in the first innings, as the hosts declare their innings at 415/9 in 106.4 Overs. Coming into bat post with England having lost half their side, Foakes, alongside his skipper Ben Stokes, stitched together a scintillating 173-run stand for the 6th wicket, which ended after Stokesâ€™ departure off pacer Kagiso Rabada. While Stokes brought up his first Test ton as Englandâ€™s Test captain, Foakes smashed his first Test match century at home, having scored his previous Test ton in Galle during his first International appearance for England in 2018. Moreover, the aforementioned partnership between the duo was the second-highest stand ever for the sixth wicket in Tests at The Emirates Old Trafford. While Stokes departed after a well compiled 103 (163) on a day when his documentary is to be released, Foakes remained unbeaten on 113* (217), as South Africa are now left to play the arduous catch-up game in a bid to Draw the Test. Ben Foakes smashes his first Test century in England The wicket-keeper batterâ€™s century moment arrived during the 102nd Over of the innings being bowled post the Tea Break, as he cut a short and wide delivery bowled by Anrich Nortje for a boundary at the Third Man region. He brought up his second Test match ton off his 206th delivery, and has put his side on the brink of victory. Social media went abuzz in praises for the 29-year-old Surrey batter, as he hit his ton after a three-year gap. newsArray.title: Home truths in tow, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan kick-off Asia Cup 2022 on Saturday
creator: Ayan Acharya
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022: When Sri Lanka, reeling from an economic crisis, meets Taliban-controlled Afghanistan in the opener on Saturday, cricket will be a great distractor for both teams.
newsArray.content: Saturdayâ€™s Asia Cup 2022 opener between Afghanistan and Sri Lanka at the Dubai International Stadium will be a crisscross of torment and catharsis for both teams. The fall of former President Gotabaya Rajapaksa in July, which followed months of protests, was greeted with joy by many in Sri Lanka. However, now, even as the country tries to retain a semblance of normalcy, the remnants of an unprecedented economic crisis continue to linger. Meanwhile, itâ€™s been more than a year since the Taliban entered Kabul unchallenged and took control of Afghanistan, which has now endured more than four decades of war. So, there is perhaps no denying the fact that cricket will be a great distractor for both teams over the next week. Afghanistanâ€™s rise as a cricketing nation has been one of the most genuine feelgood stories of the sport. The one big positive for it is that it no longer has to go into tournaments like the Asia Cup through the qualifying rounds. Afghanistanâ€™s cricket has improved to the extent where it is directly seeded in the main event. At the last T20 World Cup (2021), also played in the UAE, Afghanistan qualified directly by being in the top eight of the T20I rankings at the cut-off date. This marks a real departure for a team that has, in recent years, evolved from an associate nation to an embodiment of what can be achieved when ambition meets skill in sport. It helps that their fans are also likable. Like 32-year-old Kaleem Khan, a cab driver from Afghanistan, who has a poignant take on the state of affairs back home and why cricket is important. â€œI laugh when people say that sport and politics do not mix. Look at us, Afghans, and our struggles. We promote brotherhood and build relationships through playing. Arenâ€™t these political goals as well? Sports and politics were never apart.â€ Speaking of politics, Afghanistanâ€™s opponent on Saturday, Sri Lanka, is grappling with a crisis of its own. But cricket proved to be a solace. Recently, Australiaâ€™s tour of Sri Lanka took place under the shadow of a crippling economic upheaval. On day two of the second Test, large protests broke out on the fort overlooking the ground, and at the central intersection at Galle. â€œWeâ€™ve got protests around the ground, it really hits home how lucky we are to be travelling the world but also in some ways itâ€™s more than just being here to play cricket, you can see the impact it can have. It hasnâ€™t been lost on our group, something we speak about quite a bit,â€ Australiaâ€™s Test captain Pat Cummins had said. During the fifth ODI of the white-ball leg, the Sri Lankan fans wore yellow jerseys to thank the Australian team for touring the country. The gesture once again highlighted the beauty of sport and the power it wields. Sri Lanka has won the Asia Cup five times â€” 1986, 1997, 2004, 2008, 2014 â€” in the ODI format and the official host of this yearâ€™s Asia Cup will be eager to add to its tally. Afghanistan, on the other hand, will aim to give fans, reared on generations of heartache, a slice of unbridled joy and pride. Read more stories on Cricket.

newsArray.title: â€˜Club of PAs, security guards,â€™ Jaiveer Shergill reiterates stand after Azadâ€™s explosive letter
creator: FP Staff
newsArray.description: â€˜Club of PAs, security guards,â€™ Jaiveer Shergill reiterates stand after Azadâ€™s explosive letter
newsArray.content: New Delhi: Barely a day after Congress leader Jaiveer Shergill quit the party, veteran politician and former Jammu and Kashmir chief minister Ghulam Nabi Azadâ€™s resignation on Friday accompanied by a scathing letter to interim party chief Sonia Gandhi has once again put the spotlight on the in-fighting, chaos and lack of leadership that has riddled the Congress over the last few years.The former Union minister in his letter has blamed Rahul Gandhi for single-handedly â€œdemolishing the consultative mechanismâ€ within the party and has also taken a swipe at the Congress scionâ€™s â€œimmaturityâ€ â€”citing these as reasons among others for wanting to dissociate from the party.Reacting to Azadâ€™s resignation, Shergill who quit the Congress on Wednesday said, â€œNow a senior leader speaking about it becoming a club of PAs and security guards shows that leaders across age groups are frustrated and disappointed by this entire coterie culture that is thriving in Congress.â€The 39-year-old was one of the youngest leaders of the Congress and also a spokesperson for the party.According to media reports, after the top Congress leadership namely the Gandhi family did not give Shergill a chance to meet them and discuss his grievances for about a year, he quit the party earlier this week with pointed digs at the high command in his resignation letter.In his letter addressed to Sonia Gandhi, the 39-year-old lawyer wrote, â€œthe vision of the partyâ€™s decision makers is no longer in syncâ€¦.â€ He also called out the rampant groupism within the Congress, and cited lobbying and partiality towards a chosen few as some of the reasons why he no longer wanted to continue with the party.The Congress party which has hit a rough patch for the last several years now and hardly has a significant presence in the Lok Sabha as the principal opposition, has been hit by a string of resignations in August alone. Jaiveer Shergillâ€™s resignation from the post of the party spokesperson, is the third this month.Senior Congress leader Anand Sharma put in his papers as the chairman of the partyâ€™s steering committee for Himachal Pradesh, months ahead of the Assembly polls, citing differences with the top leadership and the way the party was functioning.Ghulam Nabi Azadâ€™s resignation on Friday, although it had been in the offing for a while, has dealt a blow to the already crumbling party and divided senior Congress leaders in their opinion with a few Congress loyalists questioning the former Union minister and his timing while a section of others subtly indicating that his letter pointed out exactly what was wrong with the party.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Shadab Khan backs bowlers to do well in Shaheen Afridiâ€™s absence Pakistanâ€™s all-rounder Shadab Khan said that the injury to Shaheen Afridi is a blow for the side, but he insists that cricket is not an individual game. He showed his faith in the pacers of the side and said that the rest of the bowlers will step in Afridiâ€™s absence. Afridi has been ruled out of the tournament with a knee injury. Although, Mohammad Wasim Jr. is also facing an injury scare, and it can be a worrying sign for Pakistan ahead of the tournament. But the beauty of cricket is that itâ€™s not an individual but a team game. So we have many match-winning bowlers in our family and I have confidence in Haris Rauf, Mohammad Wasim, Naseem Shah, Shahnawaz Dahani and others, who will surely step-up,â€ Shadab Khan said to PCB. newsArray.content: Ben Stokes drives Lungi Ngidi: The English captain played with attacking instincts in the morning session today. During the second day of the second Test of South Africaâ€™s tour of England 2022 in Manchester, England captain Ben Stokes played some eye-catching shots to not let his team get affected by the dismissals of two overnight batters. Coming in to bat at No. 6 in the 34th over, Stokes hit his first boundary of the innings off South Africa pacer Kagiso Rabada in the 39th over. On the next delivery that he faced, Stokes sat down on one knee to hit spinner Simon Harmer for a six over mid-wicket. It was in the 45th over that Stokes hit Lungi Ngidi for a boundary as the hosts continued to accumulate runs and build on their first innings lead. However, Stokes played the shot of the morning in Ngidiâ€™s next over dancing down the track to drive the right-arm bowler down the ground with a stamp of authority. â€œWow! Thatâ€™s fantastic. Use of the feet, control and the straightest of bats. High quality,â€ commentator on-duty for Sky Sports said to describe Stokesâ€™ third four of the morning. newsArray.title: Asia Cup 2022: Babar Azam on verge of 8,000 runs in T20 cricket
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022: Babar Azam on verge of 8,000 runs in T20 cricket
newsArray.content: Pakistan captain Babar Azam will have the opportunity to reach 8000 runs at the upcoming Asia Cup as he is just 120 runs away from touching the milestone. The continental tournament starts for his team with a high-voltage clash against India as the two neighbours face each other in the group stages on August 28.It will be a stiff ask of the 27-year-old batter to go past the mark in the first game as he has currently scored 7880 T20 runs in 219 matches at an average of 45.28 and a strike rate of 128.08. Azam has shot six centuries and 67 half centuries in the shortest format of the game.Touching 8K will make him the second Pakistani batter to do so as 40-year-old Shoaib Malik is currently the leading T20 run-scorer at 11,698 runs. The veteran, who is part of the T20 squad for the Asia Cup, has played 472 T20 games at an average of 36.55 and a strike rate of 127.13.Among other Pakistanis, Mohammed Rizwan is 91 runs away from 5000 T20 runs and will become the seventh batter to join the elite list behind Malik, Babar, Mohammad Hafeez, Umar Akmal, Ahmed Shehzad, and Kamran Akmal. Rizwan has been in hot form as last year he became the first batsman to score 2000 T20 runs in a calendar year.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.title: Asia Cup 2022: Suryakumar Yadav strong candidate to dethrone Babar Azam from T20I No 1 spot
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022: Suryakumar Yadav strong candidate to dethrone Babar Azam from T20I No 1 spot
newsArray.content: With hours to go for the high-voltage clash of India vs Pakistan at the Asia Cup 2022, plenty of Indians will have the opportunity to set record and personal milestones at the continental event, which has been rebranded to a T20 format.Indiaâ€™s new frontline batter Suryakumar Yadav, who is just a 115-run away from completing 5000 runs in the shortest format. A domestic stalwart, who made his international debut in March 2021, has scored the bulk of those runs in India, and 2644 of those came in the Indian Premier League.His current hot form also serves him the opportunity to replace Pakistan captain Babar Azam at the top of the T20 batting rankings. Yadav (2nd in rankings) is currently just a 13 ratings behind Azam, who has a rating of 818. Azamâ€™s opening partner Mohammad Rizwan is third with a rating of 794.But closest among all teammates to script history at the Asia Cup is Ravindra Jadeja, who requires a solitary wicket to become the nationâ€™s leading wicket-taker in the tournament. The 33-year-old all-rounder is currently joint-leader with Irfan Pathan at 22 wickets.Rishabh Pant and Hardik Pandya will also have an opportunity to touch four-digit figures in T20I as the duo is currently 117 and 166 runs away respectively from reaching 1000 runs.Opener KL Rahul, who made his comeback during the Zimbabwe tour, is also a 335 runs away from touching 2000 runs in T20I.Veteran Dinesh Karthik, on the other hand, will have the opportunity to join Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, Suresh Raina, MS Dhoni, Shikhar Dhawan and Robin Uthappa in the elite 7000-run clubs as he is just 154 runs away from the mark.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.title: Asia Cup 2022, AFG vs SL: Date, time, venue, TV channel and live streaming for Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022, AFG vs SL: Date, time, venue, TV channel and live streaming for Sri Lanka vs Afghanistan
newsArray.content: The much-anticipated Asia Cup is all set to get underway in Dubai when Sri Lanka take on Afghanistan in a Group B match on Saturday (27 August). Six teams have been divided among two groups. India, Pakistan and qualifiers Hong Kong feature in Group A, while Group B consists of Sri Lanka, Afghanistan and Bangladesh.The top two from each group qualify for the Super Four, wherein each team plays the other once and the top two teams qualify for the final, slated to be held on 11 September.The much-awaited contest of the tournament will be India vs Pakistan on 28 August but before that Sri Lanka take on Afghanistan in the opener on Saturday.Sri Lanka are without premier pacer Dushmantha Chameera, who has been ruled out of the tournament due to a leg injury.Despite Chameeraâ€™s absence, Sri Lanka still seem to have a balanced side with the likes of Wanindu Hasaranga, Maheesh Theekshana, Bhanuka Rajapaksa and Pathum Nissanka all in their ranks.Sri Lanka are five-time winners of the Asia Cup, second-most successful team in the tournament, having last won it in 2014.For Afghanistan, Hazratullah Zazai and Rahmanullah Gurbaz will look to explode as far as their batting is concerned. The likes of Hashmatullah Shahidi and Najibullah Zadran impressed in the Afghan league recently, scoring 411 and 397 runs respectively.In terms of bowling, Fareed Ahmadâ€™s pace will be a major threat, while spinners Rashid Khan and Mujeeb Ur Rahman will also play a crucial role.Hereâ€™s all you need to know about when and where to watch Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka in Asia Cup:When is the Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup game?The Asia Cup game between Sri Lanka and Afghanistan will be played on Saturday, 27 August.Where will the Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup match be held?The Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup match will be held at Dubai International Cricket Stadium in Dubai.What time is the Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup scheduled to start?The Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka match will start at 7.30 PM IST with the toss taking place half an hour earlier.Which TV channel is Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup match on?The match will be telecast across the Star Sports Network channels (both SD and HD). You can also follow LIVE updates of the match on Firstpost.com.Where to live stream Afghanistan vs Sri Lanka Asia Cup match ?The match can be live-streamed on Disney + Hotstar.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.title: Asia Cup 2022: Suryakumar Yadav a multi-dimensional player, can be utilised as a floater, says Saba Karim
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022: Suryakumar Yadav a multi-dimensional player, can be utilised as a floater, says Saba Karim
newsArray.content: Suryakumar Yadav has experienced a phenomenal rise in international cricket in recent months and is among the batters to watch out for in the upcoming edition of the Asia Cup.Pakistan pace legend Wasim Akram too has lavished praise on the â€œphenomenalâ€ Mumbaikar for his wide range of shots and his ability to bat 360 degrees.Former India wicketkeeper and selector Saba Karim to joined the chorus in support of Yadav â€” popularly known by his initials SKY â€” and added that he could be utilised as a floater in the Indian batting order in the upcoming tournament.â€œSuryakumar Yadav is such a multi-dimensional player, I can keep him as a floater. I can push him up the order, if my two openers bat says till the 7th-8th over, I can push in SKY then,â€ Saba Karim said exclusively on SPORTS18â€™s daily sports news show SPORTS OVER THE TOP. â€œOr in case it is required, I can also push him down the order because heâ€™s such a player who can give me the value at whatever number he bats and Iâ€™m looking at my 4-5-6 as floaters,â€ added Karim.Yadav, an established star in the Indian Premier League (IPL) who only broke into the Indian team last year, has been in scintillating form going into the Asia Cup, having topped the run charts in the T20I seriesâ€™ in England and West Indies, scoring his maiden international hundred in the former.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.title: Asia Cup 2022: Rohit Sharma aims to overtake Sachin Tendulkar's record among other milestones
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: Asia Cup 2022: Rohit Sharma aims to overtake Sachin Tendulkar's record among other milestones
newsArray.content: Rohit Sharma will lead an Indian team at the 2022 Asia Cup in the United Arab Emirates, hoping that the Men in Blueâ€™s performances in the tournament would give a sign as to where the team is headed ahead of the T20 World Cup in Australia.Rohit Sharma had taken over as permanent T20I skipper after the 2021 T20 World Cup, when Virat Kohli had relinquished captaincy. India had suffered a group stage exit in the T20 World Cup last year, but will look to go all the way Down Under, having last won the tournament back in 2007.As a captain, Rohit enjoys a win percentage of 80 in T20Is, and India are yet to lose a bilateral series under him. Incidentally, Rohit was India skipper when he led his team to Asia Cup glory in 2018, beating Bangladesh in the final. However, times have changed and this time it will be a different challenge altogether for the Men in Blue.Rohit can achieve a few milestones in the Asia Cup, including surpassing Virat Kohli as Indiaâ€™s second-most successful skipper. Rohit needs just two wins to surpass Virat Kohli as Indiaâ€™s second-most successful skipper, with MS Dhoni leading that chart with 41 victories.Rohit also needs 117 runs to register 1000 runs in the Asia Cup. While that record still seems quite distant, 88 more runs in Asia Cup for Rohit would see him surpass Sachin Tendulkarâ€™s tally of 971 runs.The Hitman, as Rohit is nicknamed, needs just six more sixes to overtake Shahid Afridi for most sixes at the Asia Cup. The former Pakistan cricketer has 26 sixes in the continental tournament.New Zealandâ€™s Martin Guptill (3497 runs) leads the all-time leading run-scorers list in T20Is, and Rohit Sharma (3497) requires only another 11 runs to reclaim that No 1 spot.India take on arch-rivals Pakistan on 28 August in their first match of the Asia Cup, before facing Hong Kong in their second group match on 31 August.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

creator: Dixit Bhargav
newsArray.description: Ben Stokes welcoming Simon Harmer: The English captain hit a first-ball six against the South African spinner today. During the second day of the second Test of South Africaâ€™s tour of England 2022 in Manchester, England captain Ben Stokes welcomed South Africa spinner Simon Harmer with a six to nullify early possibility of a left-handedâ€¦ The post â€œWhat a response from Stokesâ€: Michael Atherton appreciates sweet-timer Ben Stokes welcoming Simon Harmer with a six at Old Trafford appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Ben Stokes welcoming Simon Harmer: The English captain hit a first-ball six against the South African spinner today. During the second day of the second Test of South Africaâ€™s tour of England 2022 in Manchester, England captain Ben Stokes welcomed South Africa spinner Simon Harmer with a six to nullify early possibility of a left-handed batter facing trouble against an off-spinner. Harmer, who bowled a solitary over on Day 1, was introduced into the attack by South Africa captain Dean Elgar in the 40th over. A loopy full-toss, Harmerâ€™s first delivery of the day, was hit by England wicket-keeper batter Ben Foakes through the covers for a four. With Foakes running a single on the third delivery, an exciting contest between Stokes and Harmer commenced with the batter putting on display first signs of aggression. Stokes, who sat on one knee, dispatched a pretty ordinary delivery for a six through the mid-wicket region. â€œWhat a response from [Ben] Stokes. Sweet-timer, into the stands for six. Wondered whether his approach against spin would be an aggressive one. First signs of aggression from Stokes,â€ former England captain Michael Atherton said while calling the match for Sky Sports. Ben Stokes welcoming Simon Harmer with a six at Old Trafford First maximum of the innings! Scorecard/clips: https://t.co/e4go7z2x78 #ENGvSA pic.twitter.com/GdpsjWpitg â€” England Cricket (@englandcricket) August 26, 2022 Resuming Day 2 from 111/3, England lost both their overnight batters within the first hour. Continuing his wicket-taking form, South Africa fast bowler Anrich Nortje dismissed Jonny Bairstow (49) and Zac Crawley (38) in successive overs to keep the hosts in control at Old Trafford. Readers must note that Nortje had picked wickets in back-to-back overs in the first Test at Lordâ€™s as well. Having just completed a 50-run partnership for the sixth wicket, Stokes and Foakes hitting six fours and a six between them has powered Englandâ€™s first innings lead to be in vicinity of 50 runs. England, who have ample time with them, would be looking to gain a gargantuan lead to put the visitors under pressure in the second innings and push for another early finish to a Test match. The post â€œWhat a response from Stokesâ€: Michael Atherton appreciates sweet-timer Ben Stokes welcoming Simon Harmer with a six at Old Trafford appeared first on The SportsRush.
